For some people, the juxtaposition of a sectarian civil war unimpeded by intense diplomatic effort has a familiar ring and that ring recalls the war in Bosnia in the early 1990s.
Yugoslavia had come undone.

Lord David Owen, the former British foreign secretary, was the European Union's negotiator for the Balkans and he joins us now from London.
Welcome to the program once again.
Nice to be here.
And when you've written recently about Syria, you've invoked the experience of Bosnia Herzegovina.
Do you feel a resonance of Bosnia in the current diplomacy over Syria?
Yeah, I think it's very like it was in September/October 1992, a complete mess.
And it doesn't surprise me these negotiations have been very difficult to establish and will take time.
In those days, some faulted you for advancing a peace plan which accepted the facts on the ground and it was said, by doing so, rewarded Serb aggression.
How did diplomats solve this problem?
How do you reconcile the desire to, say, keep the Syrian regime at the table, even though it's a regime that, we heard yesterday, tortured and murdered detainees by the thousands?
It is very difficult.
I mean, if you stay in judgment with them, if you start taking sides, of course, you'll be no use at all.
So the main thing is to be extremely polite.

There will not be a resolution in Syria without some very messy compromises.

I don't think you can pack up fighting unfortunately at this stage.
